options.label: C
options.text: Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon

questions.correct_answer: A. The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.

How long should digoxin be withheld to reach a safer yet probably therapeutic level of 1 ng/ml?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- 3.2 days:

Number of half-lives

1

2

3

4

Percentage of drug remaining

50%

25%

12.5%

6.25%

Characteristic First-Order Kinetics Zero-Order Kinetics
Rate of Reaction Dependent on concentration of the substrate Constant rate of reaction regardless of the substrate concentration
Reaction Rate Equation Rate = k * [A] Rate = k
Half-Life Constant and independent of initial concentration of substrate Not applicable (no defined half-life)
Example Most drug elimination processes (e.g., metabolism, renal excretion) Aspirin metabolism at high doses, alcohol metabolism at high doses
Saturation Effect Absent (rate of elimination proportional to concentration) Present (enzyme or transporter becomes saturated at high concentrations)
Clinical Relevance Generally safer as overdose can be managed by adjusting dosing regimen based on concentration Risk of toxicity increases at higher doses, as elimination rate becomes saturated
Graphical Representation Exponential decay curve Flat-line (straight horizontal line)

Classification Fungus (formerly classified as a protozoan)
Infection Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), an opportunistic infection affecting the lungs in immunocompromised individuals
Transmission Likely via airborne route
Predisposing Factors - HIV/AIDS- Organ transplantation- Immunosuppressive therapy- Certain malignancies
Clinical Presentation - Dry cough
- Shortness of breath
- Fever
- Chest discomfort
Diagnosis - Chest X-ray or CT scan- Microscopic examination of respiratory specimens- PCR testing
Treatment Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the primary treatment
Prophylaxis Recommended for individuals at high risk (e.g., HIV patients with low CD4 counts)
Prevention - Antiretroviral therapy for HIV/AIDS patients- Prophylactic antibiotics in high-risk patients
Epidemiology Common among immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS

questions.text: First, add a few crystals of ferrous sulfate to 5 ml of gastric aspirate. Then, add 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. Boil the mixture and then allow it to cool. Afterward, add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid. If the solution turns a 'greenish-blue color,' this indicates the presence of cyanide in the aspirate. What is the name of this bedside test?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Lee Jones T

Test Purpose and Description Positive Result
Lee Jones Test Purpose: To detect the presence of cyanide in gastric aspirate. Description: A few crystals of ferrous sulfate are added to gastric aspirate, followed by 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. The mixture is boiled and then cooled, after which 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid are added. A greenish-blue color indicates the presence of cyanide. Greenish-blue color
Marquis Test Purpose: To identify specific drugs or substances in gastric aspirate. Description: The Marquis reagent is used to test for the presence of various drugs, including opioids and amphetamines. The aspirate is mixed with the reagent, and color changes are observed, providing presumptive identification of the substance. Color changes specific to the detected substance.
Marsh Test Purpose: To detect and quantify arsenic in gastric aspirate. Description: The Marsh Test involves the reduction of arsenic compounds to arsine gas (AsH3), which is then detected using various methods, such as flame or graphite furnace atomic absorption spectroscopy. Generation of arsine gas, which can be quantified.
Silver Nitrate Test Purpose: To detect the presence of chloride salts, such as sodium chloride, in gastric aspirate, which may indicate poisoning with toxic substances like mercuric chloride. Description: Silver nitrate solution is added to the aspirate. Formation of a white precipitate (silver chloride) suggests the presence of chloride salts. Formation of white precipitate.
Phenolphthalein Test Purpose: To detect the presence of strong acids or bases in gastric aspirate, which may indicate corrosive substance ingestion. Description: Phenolphthalein solution is added to the aspirate. A color change (pink for bases or colorless for acids) indicates the nature of the substance ingested. Pink or colorless solution.
Dithiothreitol (DTT) Test Purpose: To detect paraquat poisoning in gastric aspirate. Description: DTT is added to the aspirate, and a color change from yellow to colorless or clear indicates the presence of paraquat. Color change from yellow to colorless or clear.

A primigravida presents at 30 weeks gestation with nausea and dizziness every time she lies down. She states that the symptoms subside when she turns on her side. Which of the following is the best explanation of such a presentation?
questions.explanation:
Supine hypotension syndrome
  • Nausea and dizziness in a pregnant female lying down are due to IVC compression, which resolves if the patient lies on her side as the compression is removed.
  • The gravid uterus compresses the IVC, thus reducing the venous return leading to supine hypotension syndrome.

Advantages of Left Lateral Position:

  • Improves uteroplacental circulation
  • Increase Fetal Oxygen saturation

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with swelling of his left parotid gland and pain, especially during chewing. He had experienced ten such episodes lasting 10–15 days each in the previous 2 years. Physical examination revealed a swollen left parotid gland with local tenderness and erythema of the overlying skin. The immunological evaluation revealed an IgA level of less than 7 mg/dl. Selective IgA deficiency
  • Most common primary immunodeficiency with low IgA and normal IgG, IgM levels.
  • Patients are susceptible to respiratory and gastrointestinal infections, atopy and anaphylaxis to IgA in blood products.
  • Patients develop IgE antibodies against the IgA antibodies present in transfused blood.
  • This sensitization can result in susceptibility to anaphylaxis on subsequent transfusion.

References:

  • ↳ Paraphilias (sexual deviations or perversions ) are sexual preference disorders in which sexual arousals occur frequently and significantly in response to objects that are not normally associated with sexual arousals, such as nonhuman objects, self or sexual partner suffering, humiliation, children, or non-consenting person.

The telephoner (usually male) verbally exposes his preoccupations and induces the recipient to talk about her sexual activity. questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study designs. What is the similarity between Cross-sectional study design and Ecological study design?

options.label: A
options.text: Both studies are done at a point of time

options.label: C
options.text: Both are based on primary data

options.label: D
options.text: The unit of study is the population

questions.correct_answer: A. Both studies are done at a point of time
questions.explanation:
Cross-Sectional Study Ecological Study
Both studies are done at a point of time
  • This study is based on primary data i.e. collected by the Investigator himself from House to House.
  • It provides “Prevalence”, so Also known as Prevalence Study
  • It is also known as the “SNAPSHOT Study”.
  • This study is based on Secondary Data i.e. Collected data from the records of the hospital. Data is not collected by Investigator himself.
  • It is used in Nutritional Surveys
  • The strength of association/prevalence cannot be calculated.
  • The unit of study is population and results are extrapolated and projected not on Individuals but on the total population.
  • This drawback is known as the “Ecological Fallacy”.

questions.explanation:
Pre renal Renal (ATN) Post renal
Urine osmolality > 500 mOsm

 

 ~ 300 mOsm

 

 <400 mOsm
Urine sodium <20 mmol/dl >20 mmol/dl

 

 Variable
FeNa <1 >1 Variable
Urine microscopic findings Hyaline casts Muddy brown casts

 

 Normal or RBC/WBC
BUN: creatinine ratio >20:1 (normal 10:1)

 

 <20:1

 

 >20:1

Prerenal injury: decreased renal blood flow resulting from sepsis, trauma, bleeding, or poor cardiac output

 

 Prolonged low-volume states, such as sepsis, decreased blood pressure, and hemorrhage
  • Such drugs as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents or cyclooxygenase Inhibitors, which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis; in turn, inhibition triggers action of vasoconstrictors on renal arterioles, which decreases glomerular filtration rate.
Intrinsic injury: acute tubular necrosis from sepsis and renal ischemia (mean arterial pressure below 70 mmHg ) and ultimately, from poor organ perfusion and multisystemic failure

 

 Nephropathy caused by contrast agents
  • Aminoglycoside drug therapy without careful dosage monitoring
Postrenal: obstructive nephropathy resulting from mechanical obstruction of urine flow

 

 Renal calculi
  • Tumors
  • Prostatic hypertrophy
  • Strictures
  • Congenital defects

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intestinal obstruction has been admitted to the surgical ward. The conservative treatment does not relieve his symptoms. He has been taken for immediate surgery. The anaesthesia with inhaled anaesthetic has been started. Which of the following factor decreases the MAC of the inhaled anaesthetic?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Lithiu

Increase in MAC

  • Hyperthermia
  • Hypernatraemia
  • Drug induced elevation of CNS catecholamine stores
  • Chronic alcohol abuse & chronic opioid abuse
  • Increases in ambient pressure (Experimental)
  • Cyclosporine
  • Excess pheomelanin production (Red hair)

 

 

 

Decrease in MAC

  • Hypothermia & Hyperthermia (if >42 oC)
  • Hyponatraemia
  • Drug-induced decrease in CNS catecholamine level
  • Increasing age (6% decrease/decade)
  • Preoperative medication
  • Hypoxemia (PAO2 <38mm Hg)
  • Hypotension(<40 mm hg-MAP)
  • Anemia (Hematocrit <10%)
  • Pregnancy ( progesterone)
  • Postpartum(returns to normal in 24-72 hours)
  • CNS depressant drugs Opioids, Benzodiazepines TCA's etc.
  • Other drugs-lithium, Lidocaine, Magnesium
  • Acute alcohol abuse
  • Cardiopulmonary bypass

  • ↳ Antiphospholipid (any of lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, anti-β glycoprotein I)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib , and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes . What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Accelerated phase of CML

The patient is considered to be in accelerated phase if any of the following are true:

  • The blood samples have 15% or more but fewer than 30% blasts.
  • Basophils make up 20% or more of the blood cells.
  • Blasts and promyelocytes combined makeup 30% or more of the blood.
  • Very low platelet counts (100 x 1,000/cubic meter or less) that are not caused by treatment.
  • New chromosomes changes in the leukaemic cells with the Philadelphia chromosomes

Treatment options are as follows:

  • Patients who present with or evolve to blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • Patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase or patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response).
  • The most effective is stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient presents to the neurology clinic with weakness in both lower extremities, progressively worsening tingling and numbness, and difficulty getting up from the chair. Aspect Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) Disease and Neuropathy

  - Contrasts with pseudo-hypertrophy of calf muscles seen in Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
Contractures - Foot contractures due to nerve involvement, leading to walking difficulties

  (a variant of Gullian-Barre Syndrome)

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the paediatrician with complaints of fever and a sharp cough for 1 week. He gives no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals mild conjunctivitis with some pus. An x-ray chest of the patient was done, which confirmed pneumonia. No organisms are seen on the Gram stain of the pus. What is the most likely causative agent in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: An obligate intracellular organism unable to make its own ATP

options.label: B
options.text: A diplococcus that has a high potential to cause blindness as well as the pneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: An organism that has no peptidoglycan or other cell-wall polymer

options.label: D
options.text: An obligate intracellular organism with infective vascular endothelium

questions.correct_answer: A. An obligate intracellular organism unable to make its own ATP

Although it is usually still possible to identify the presence of drugs, the constituent chemicals in embalming fluids affect not only the detection but also the rate of decay of the majority of both pharmaceutical and illicit drugs in blood and many other bodily tissues, making forensic evidence unsafe and, therefore, usually inadmissible in courts of law. Which tissue sample will the forensic team prefer in this case for toxicological analysis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Skeletal mu

questions.text: A 30-month-old deaf boy whose development is slower than normal is being followed for congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in your clinic. The child's mother is pregnant again and is worried about her new baby. Which of the followin g is advisory information to be given to the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The mother has antibodies to CMV that is passed to the fetus

options.label: B
options.text: The mother’s infection cannot become reactivated

options.label: D
options.text: The new infant should be isolated from the older child

questions.correct_answer: A. The mother has antibodies to CMV that is passed to the fetus
questions.explanation:
Congenital CMV
  • CMV is the most common cause of congenital infections
  • In primary CMV infection in the first trimester of pregnancy, most of these babies die, and those who survive are severely affected
  • However, most in secondary maternal infection infants infected are asymptomatic and 10% of them eventually manifest hearing and neurologic problems because maternal IgG antibodies pass transplacentally and protect the baby against infection
  • Some authorities recommend keeping a child with congenital CMV infection away from susceptible pregnant women because CMV excretion can persist for months to years

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has been brought in for admission in a semiconscious state. She was found by her roommate in her hostel room with some bottles of alcohol and some drugs by her side. On observation, the patient's hands were seen moving in a pill-rolling pattern. Occasionally she was also threading imaginary needles.This is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Datura poisoning

questions.text: A healthcare delivery system is an organization of people, institutions, and resources to deliver healthcare services to meet the health needs of a target population. Committee Main Points
Bhore committee

  • Social physician
  • Comprehensive healthcare concept
Balwant Rai committee
  • Panchayati Raj institutions
  • 3 tier rural health infrastructure
Chadda committee
  • Maintenance phase of the National Malaria eradication programme
  • 1 basic health worker/10,000 population
Mukherjee Committee
  • Basic health services
Jungalwala committee
  • Integration of health services
  • Equal pay for equal work
Kartar Singh committee
  • Multi-purpose worker concept
Srivastava committee
  • Bands of semi and paraprofessional health workers, village health guides, Health assistant
  • ROME scheme (Reorientation of Medical Education)
High-level expert group committee
  • Universal Health Coverage

Intracapsular Extracapsular
Less Common More Common
60 years 80 years

Increased external rotation > 45o (as it is extracapsular)
